children.subject:
The answer is to make time. Most, if not all, of us can't do everything. Assuming you're not a transfer, you have enough time to take a fair amount of EECS upper divs without having to take 3 per semester (I'm personally not doing more than 2 per semester, until the semester right before I graduate probably). Chances are you might be including too many courses that you'd like to take because you may have a passing interest in them, and if so, I suggest culling that list, so that it can align best with your goals. Do you have a certain sub-domain/ field of interest in mind? Are you trying to go to grad school? If so, leetcode isn't going to matter, research + taking a bunch of courses pertinent to that field (and doing well in them) will. Are you heavily interested in industry? If so, focus on prioritizing the core SWE classes, recruiting apps, and on interview prep. Do you really need to take 189 and 127 and 126 all together in your sophomore fall/spring semester? Not unless you're prioritizing ML specifically, and again, possibly grad school for the same. Your goals will go a long way in determining how you manage your time the next couple years, and personally speaking, the quicker you can make a decision as to what your goal is going to be, the more time you have to hit it. And once you make up your mind, ignore the noise as to what everyone else may be taking and doing and stick to your goals. 

I'm not a senior and hence I'm not posting in the student response above, but these are my two cents.

Agree with the follow-up above, make it a habit, just apply to at least 3 jobs a day and do 30 min. of prep. That's something you can make time for no matter how busy you get. Also wrote more about my experience/advice @9139

I'd like to ask, if I plan to take 61B+170 the next semester, but the job-hunting (fall season recruiting) starts at this summer, then how should I prepare for the algorithm/data structure interview questions? Should I look over the webcast for 61B in previous semesters? Thanks!

If you don’t be have plans this summer, and if the cash hit isn’t too much(maybe you have aid) 61B in Summer with CCI then leetcode.

idk if I recommend 61b and 170 at same time. 61b is a pre req. I’m sure you’ll be okay..but idk I never thought about how one could take at same time.

if you will, I personally would do Josh Hug 61b vids and slides, or a good data structure book. Then yes, CCI then leetcode. You should also get familiar with Java.

It’s hard to say what you should cut out, idk your ambitions or what you’re willing to sacrifice or how fast you get things, but I recommend 2 techs max per semester, sleeping same 8 hour schedule daily, eating healthy at times that benefit you and don’t make you tired, exercise 30 min a day, slowly cut out non meaningful things like internet scrolling, YouTube, and worrying about little things(read books like “don’t sweat the Small stuff” or “the happiness advantage” or “end of stress”), surround yourself with good ppl who care about you.

start prep now. Cracking coding interview, if you feel time is scarce, do 30 min a day, everyday. Stay on timeline of a course, even front load if you have time through past slides or notes. Ask a lot of questions when you have them on piazza. Have a study group, get resume checked by others.

To balance two time consuming things, you must prepare beforehand and continue preparing while, and have efficient ways of doing them. Spending 5 hours on a bug might not be in your best interest, so the study group can help.

we all solve problems at a different pace, so the more free time you have, the better regardless.

history.content:
Hi! As a freshman, I'd like to ask a sincere question for more senior students: How did you plan your time to balance internship job-hunting (recruiting) and academic? According to my current pre-planed schedule for the upcoming years, I may have to take 3 EECS courses per semester, and it seems I can't avoid taking high-workload courses together, such as two courses from 162,186,164,189 in one semester plus an lighter tech course. In this case, how can I still have time to work on the leetcode, etc?

Thanks!
history.subject: Advice for balancing internship job-hunting (recruiting) and academic?
